Cheruthoni’s critical infrastructure, such as roads & the main bridge connecting 2 ends of the town, were severely damaged during the 2018 Kerala floods.

Nasar, an autorickshaw driver, narrates how Cheruthoni is now climate-proofing its infrastructure

The 2018 flood isolated Kerala's Cheruthoni and washed away homes. The people vowed never to lose their livelihood in  another event and fought for climate-proof infrastructure.

Let's invest in resilient and sustainable infrastructure.

Congratulations to the team behind the 2018 film for being chosen as India's official entry for the Oscars. We, as Malayalis, will always remember the challenges of the 2018 flood. Congratulations once again. 
By the way, I don't think the 2018 movie deserves an Oscar, neither…

Kerala witnessed its greatest act of kindness, or 'nanma', during the time of the floods. Human beings, regardless of religion, caste, politics, gender, and age, came together to help one another. This 'nanma' is the reason why Kerala survived that calamity. So, what's wrong with…

The one issue I found with '2018' is in how it sidelines the efforts of the govt machinery during the floods, just like how Aashiq Abu did with 'Virus' on how Kerala overcame the Nipah Virus threat. Anyone with a memory of those days will know that this is not true
